conclusion: Consider the electric field due to the two point charges at points M and N.
Charges at points M and N are +Q and -Q, respectively.
Distance from point B to points M and N is L since MNB is an equilateral triangle.
Electric field due to a point charge Q at a distance r is given by E = kQ/r^2.
Electric field at B due to charge +Q at M is E_M = kQ/L^2.
Electric field at B due to charge -Q at N is E_N = kQ/L^2.
Electric field due to +Q at M points away from M.
Electric field due to -Q at N points towards N.
Fields at B due to M and N are at an angle of 60° to each other since MNB is an equilateral triangle.
Components of electric fields along the line connecting M and N cancel out because they are equal and opposite.
Perpendicular components of electric fields add up to E_resultant = 2(kQ/L^2)cos(30°).
Resultant electric field at B is E_resultant = √3kQ/L^2.
Force on the ball with charge +q in the electric field is F = qE_resultant.
Substituting the resultant electric field, F = q(√3kQ/L^2) = √3kQq/L^2.
Magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball when it reaches point B is √3kQq/L^2.
